thread.title: Barnes hoping Jordan Bone has repeat performance against Vandy
thread.title_full: Barnes hoping Jordan Bone has repeat performance against Vandy

title: Barnes hoping Jordan Bone has repeat performance against Vandy
text:
Slot to Tennessee Links 
Rick Barnes was asked Monday whether or not certain players play better against certain teams. Unfortunately, the second-year Tennessee basketball coach has proof that sometimes that's the case. 
"I know one thing, J.J. Frazier plays really well against us," Barnes said of the Georgia senior guard who lit up Thompson-Boling Arena with 29 points to rally his Bulldogs to a win on Feb. 11. "So maybe the answer to your question is yes." 
(Want the latest scoop on Tennessee football and basketball? Make sure you're in the loop — take five seconds to sign up for our FREE Vols newsletter now!) 
This week Barnes would prefer freshman point guard Jordan Bone channels his inner J.J. Frazier, who has totaled 57 points in his last two meetings against the Vols. 
Last time Tennessee (15-12, 7-7 SEC) played Vanderbilt (14-13, 7-7), Bone dropped a career-high 23 points in an 87-75 win at Memorial Gymnasium in Nashville on Jan. 14. 
The Vols meet the Commodores again on Wednesday (TV: SEC Network, 6:30 p.m.) at Thompson-Boling Arena. (Photo: Tennessee athletics, UTSports.com) 
"I hope in this situation Jordan will play the same way he played and do it even better," Barnes said. "I guess that’s been his best game all year and it was a big night for him." 
Bone, the Nashville native from Ensworth School, went back to his hometown and shot the lights out, making 8 of 12 attempts from the floor and 4 of 5 from the 3-point line. 
Bone had only made 1 of 10 3-point attempts before erupting against the Commodores. 
"We just want to see him and the rest of the guys be consistent and we need a lot of guys to play well from here on out," Barnes said. "Robert (Hubbs) went through a period and it’s nice to see him bounce back the other night." 
Hubbs responded from 24 minutes, tied for a season low, and seven points in last week's 83-58 loss at No. 11 Kentucky to score 21 points in Saturday's 90-70 win over Missouri. 
"I was really proud of the way he came back," Barnes said of Hubbs. "He had struggled for about a week-and-a-half where he wasn’t able to practice much. 
"Jordan is getting better, but he still has to sustain it. He still doesn’t sustain it the way we need it, but he is definitely trying." 
Finding comfort at home of late, Bone has sustained an elite assist-to-turnover ratio. In his last four games at Thompson-Boling Arena, he has 20 assists to just three turnovers. 
"I think different point guards play the game differently," Barnes said. " Jordan Bone and Lamonte Turner both play the position in different ways. I think what you want is a 3-to-1 ratio, if you can get it, with assists to turnovers. 
"That is what you like to have because you want those guys to have the ball in their hands as much as possible and anything better would be awesome. I just don’t want guys to turn the ball over." 
Tennessee has averaged 9.5 turnovers as a team over its last four home games, while averaging 17.8 assists. The ratio over the last two home games, against Missouri and Georgia, has been 19.0 assists to 7.0 turnovers. 
"As a team (you hope) to keep it under 10 if you can, because turnovers lead to easy baskets for the other team and really hurt you when you are trying to get your defense set," Barnes said. "I do like it as a team when we are sharing the ball and we are assisting on most of our baskets."
